synthesis_summary: This run's seven UI elements collectively solve the crisis revealed by the Susan-Bryant call: Split Lease has no independent system image, no substitute signifiers for physical inspection, and no self-service path for guests who think in months and weekdays rather than night counts. The elements form a complete guest journey from discovery ('Book the nights you need') through listing evaluation (layered trust verification stack with verified photos, cancellation guarantee, and host identity), proposal creation (natural-language schedule and duration selectors with real-time translation), negotiation (timeline with predictive waiting and heartbeat feedback), acceptance (grounded confirmation with next-steps roadmap), to move-in (chronological House Manual with interactive verification checklist and persistent cancellation safety banner). Every element uses Don Norman's affordance/signifier/feedback framework to make invisible platform affordances discoverable, replace human-mediated trust with structured evidence, and map platform controls to the guest's natural vocabulary. The elements are built on the production purple palette (#31135D primary) and are designed to function without any human intermediary â€” the exact capability Susan's call revealed is missing.

elements.name: Platform Identity Hero Section
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan misidentified Split Lease as a real estate brokerage because no page communicates what the service is without human explanation.
elements.description: A landing page hero section that communicates the Split Lease model in under 5 seconds using the guest's natural vocabulary. The headline 'Book the nights you need. Skip the ones you don't.' triggers immediate comprehension relief. Below, three concrete examples show real schedule patterns (Mon-Fri, 3 nights/week, weekends only) with mini day-badge visualizations, making the abstract 'non-continuous nights' concept instantly concrete. A search entry point with schedule presets lets the guest begin searching immediately.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical flex, centered. Hero headline at top, subtitle below, three example cards in a horizontal row, search CTA at bottom.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) with subtle gradient overlay at top

typography.heading: Inter, 36px (--text-4xl), 700 weight, color #31135D
typography.accent: Inter, 12px (--text-sm), 600 weight, color rgb(82, 31, 147) for schedule badges

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) for headline establishes brand authority. Text gray for subtitle keeps it subordinate. Purple-tinted off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) for example card backgrounds connects to brand. Schedule badges use text-purple for the identity signifier system.

interaction_spec.default_state: Headline, subtitle, three example cards, and search CTA visible on load. No animation on entry -- content is simply present, confident and unhurried.
interaction_spec.hover: Example cards lift with shadow-md on hover. Search CTA shows gradient-purple-hover.
interaction_spec.click: Search CTA navigates to search results with schedule preset pre-selected if an example card was clicked.
interaction_spec.animation: Day badges in example cards use a subtle stagger fade-in (100ms delay per badge) to draw the eye to the schedule visualization.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, example cards stack vertically. Headline drops to 28px (--text-2xl). Day badges remain the same size (32px) for touch targets.

copy_spec.primary_text: Book the nights you need. Skip the ones you don't.
copy_spec.secondary_text: Private rooms and apartments, by the night. Pick your schedule, find your space.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Example labels: 'Weekdays Mon-Fri', '3 nights/week', 'Weekends only'. CTA: 'Find a space'

elements.html_css:
Book the nights you need.
Skip the ones you don't.

Private rooms and apartments, by the night. Pick your schedule, find your space.

Weekdays
Mon–Fri
M T W T F S S
5 nights/week · from $65/night
Flexible
3 nights/week
M T W T F S S
3 nights/week · from $75/night
Weekends
Sat–Sun
M T W T F S S
2 nights/week · from $85/night
Find a space
elements.test_strategy: Five-second usability test (tests-001): show landing page for 5 seconds to 20 participants unfamiliar with Split Lease. Target: 70%+ correctly identify Split Lease as a part-time or partial-week housing service. Zero participants should misidentify it as a real estate brokerage or hotel.
elements.coherence_notes: Reinforces works-001 from prior runs (human-to-digital handoff). First element in the library to use Don Norman's system image principle. Schedule badges use the same visual language (purple pill on off-white) as listing card badges, creating a persistent identity signifier system across pages.

elements.name: Listing Trust Verification Stack
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan demanded physical inspection three times because the listing had no discoverable substitute signifiers for in-person verification.
elements.description: A listing page header component that places three trust signifiers above the fold in a layered stack: (1) a verified photo gallery with a 'Verified by Split Lease' badge, (2) a first-night cancellation guarantee displayed at the same visual prominence as the price, and (3) a host identity card with response time and guest count. The stack follows Susan's decision sequence: see the space (photos) then know I can leave (guarantee) then know the host is real (identity).

visual_spec.layout: Vertical stack. Photo gallery (full width, 280px height) with verification badge overlay at top-left. Below: two-column row with price + guarantee badge on the left and host identity card on the right.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) on host identity card
visual_spec.border_radius: 12px (--rounded-xl) for photo gallery, 8px (--rounded-lg) for guarantee badge, 12px for host card

typography.heading: Inter, 20px (--text-xl), 700 weight, color #1a1a1a for listing title
typography.body: DM Sans, 14px (--text-base), 400 weight, color #374151 for descriptions
typography.accent: Inter, 12px (--text-sm), 600 weight, white on #31135D for verification badge

spacing.gap: 16px between stack layers, 12px between badge elements

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) semi-transparent overlay for verification badge -- brand color as trust signal. Secondary purple for guarantee badge text. Neutral colors for host card to frame the host as a real person.

interaction_spec.default_state: Photo gallery with swipe/arrow navigation, verification badge pinned top-left, guarantee badge and host card visible below without scrolling.
interaction_spec.hover: Photo gallery arrows appear on hover. Host card shows subtle shadow-md elevation. Guarantee badge shows underline on hover to indicate expandable detail.
interaction_spec.click: Guarantee badge click opens a detail sheet (slide up, 200ms) with full cancellation terms. Host card click navigates to host profile. Photo gallery supports full-screen view.
interaction_spec.animation: Verification badge fades in with the gallery (250ms). Guarantee badge is static -- no attention-grabbing animation, just permanent presence like a structural element.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, host card moves below price row. Photo gallery becomes full-width swipeable. Guarantee badge stays adjacent to price.

copy_spec.primary_text: Rita's Private Room · North Bergen, NJ
copy_spec.secondary_text: Private Room · Private Bath · Host present weekday evenings
copy_spec.micro_copy: Badge: 'Verified by Split Lease'. Guarantee: 'Cancel within 24 hours if the space doesn't match'. Host card: 'Rita · Responds in 2 hours · 12 prior guests'

elements.html_css:
Private Room · Verified Photos
Verified by Split Lease
1 / 8 photos

Rita's Private Room · North Bergen, NJ

Private Room · Private Bath · Host present weekday evenings
$85 /night
First-night cancellation
guarantee
R
Rita
Responds in 2 hours · 12 prior guests
No tours before booking — for the host's privacy. We verify every listing with photos, and you can cancel within 24 hours if the space doesn't match.
elements.test_strategy: A/B test (tests-002): split traffic between current listing page and redesigned page with trust triad. Target: 25%+ higher listing-to-proposal conversion for first-time unassisted guests. Eye-tracking study (tests-007): verify trust triad is fixated within first 6 seconds of scan path.
elements.coherence_notes: Extends the library's existing trust credential work from the host side (Kahneman lens) to the guest side (Norman lens). The no-preview policy explanation transforms an invisible anti-affordance into a signified constraint with visible alternatives. Layer 6 flagged trust as the strongest cross-layer signal; this element is its primary implementation.

elements.name: Space Composition Listing Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan's first three questions were about room type, bathroom, and co-occupancy -- but conventional listing cards lead with price and location, burying the primary decision variables for shared housing.
elements.description: A listing card for search results that leads with a three-part space composition label (room type, bathroom privacy, co-occupancy) as the first text element after the photo. A schedule availability badge sits on the photo. The card answers the guest's three prerequisite questions in a single scan line before presenting price and location.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card. Photo with schedule badge overlay, then space composition label, then price, then location.

typography.heading: Inter, 15px, 600 weight, color #1a1a1a for listing name
typography.body: Inter, 12px (--text-sm), 500 weight, color #1a1a1a for space composition; 400 weight, #6b7280 for co-occupancy
typography.accent: Inter, 11px (--text-xs), 600 weight, uppercase, color rgb(82, 31, 147) for schedule badge

visual_spec.color_usage: Schedule badge uses text-purple on off-white pill (identity signifier system). Space composition uses neutral text-dark for factual descriptors. Co-occupancy uses softer text-gray because it is contextual. Mid-dot separator in text-light-gray.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card shows photo with schedule badge, space composition label, price, and location. All visible without interaction.
interaction_spec.hover: Card lifts with shadow-md. Subtle scale 1.01.
interaction_spec.click: Navigates to full listing detail page.
interaction_spec.animation: Cards fade in with 50ms stagger when search results load.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, cards stack single-column full-width. Photo height reduces to 180px. Space composition stays single line or wraps to two lines max.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Private Room · Private Bath · Host present evenings
copy_spec.micro_copy: Schedule badge: 'WEEKNIGHTS'. Price: '$85/night'. Location: 'North Bergen, NJ · Near Lincoln Tunnel'

elements.html_css:

elements.test_strategy: Five-second test on listing cards: show search results for 5 seconds and ask 'What kind of space is the first listing?' Target: 85%+ correctly identify room type and bathroom privacy. A/B test card design against current layout measuring click-through rate to listing detail.
elements.coherence_notes: Complements the existing Schedule-First Listing Cards (guest-communicates-006) from the Nneka run. Layer 6 recommended making the primary listing card element contextually adaptive. For shared housing guests like Susan's friend, space composition precedes schedule; for hybrid workers, schedule may precede. Both should be primary elements.

elements.name: Natural-Language Stay Configurator
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan thinks in months and weekday names but the platform requires night counts -- Bryant had to translate the vocabulary twice during the call.
elements.description: A proposal configuration component with preset-based schedule pills (Weekdays, Weekends, Full Week, Custom) and duration cards (About 1 month, About 2 months, 3+ months) that accept the guest's natural vocabulary. A real-time translation summary bar below shows both languages simultaneously: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights at $85/night = $3,400 total'. Every selection produces immediate visual feedback within 200ms.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical stack. Schedule presets row (horizontal pills), duration presets row (horizontal cards), translation summary bar below.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) for container, var(--bg-light) for summary bar
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) for inactive elements, secondary-purple for active
visual_spec.border_radius: 20px (--rounded-pill) for preset pills, 12px for duration cards, 8px for summary bar

typography.heading: Inter, 14px (--text-base), 600 weight for section labels
typography.body: Inter, 14px, 500 weight for summary bar text
typography.accent: Inter, 14px, 600 weight for preset pill labels

spacing.gap: 8px between pills, 12px between duration cards, 24px between sections

visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for active preset backgrounds and active duration card borders. White text on active pills. Text-dark on inactive pills. bg-off-white for active duration card backgrounds. bg-light for summary bar.

interaction_spec.default_state: All presets inactive (neutral gray background). Summary bar shows placeholder: 'Select a schedule and duration to see your stay details.'
interaction_spec.hover: Inactive pills show bg-light-gray darkening. Duration cards show subtle shadow.
interaction_spec.click: Tapping a preset pill: background transitions to secondary-purple with white text (150ms). Summary bar updates with opacity pulse (0.5 to 1.0, 300ms). Duration cards show purple border with off-white fill on selection.
interaction_spec.animation: Summary bar text updates with a brief pulse animation to draw attention to the changed value. 'Custom' option reveals calendar grid via height-expand (300ms).
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, preset pills wrap to two rows if needed. Duration cards stack 2x2 grid. Summary bar stays full-width and sticky at bottom during scroll.

copy_spec.micro_copy: Pills: 'Weekdays', 'Weekends', 'Full Week', 'Custom'. Duration: 'About 1 month', 'About 2 months', '3+ months'. Warning: 'Rita requires at least 30 nights. Add 2 more weeks.'

elements.html_css:
Choose your schedule
How long do you need?
About 1 month
≈ 20 nights
About 2 months
≈ 40 nights
3+ months
≈ 60+ nights
Mon–Fri for 2 months = 40 nights · $85/night · $3,400 total
elements.test_strategy: Moderated usability test (tests-003): give 15 participants the scenario 'weekdays for about 2 months'. Target: 80%+ complete configuration in under 60 seconds. Zero participants confused about night count translation. 70%+ use the summary bar to verify.
elements.coherence_notes: Validates the vocabulary-first principle now confirmed from both sides of the marketplace: hosts think in monthly rent (Kahneman lens), guests think in months and weekdays (Norman lens). The same coupled-input pattern should appear in the Date Change Tool during active lease for consistency.

elements.name: Proposal Negotiation Timeline
elements.problem_it_solves: When the phone call dropped for 20 seconds, Susan and Bryant scrambled with 'Can you hear me?' -- the platform's asynchronous negotiation must never feel like silence.
elements.description: A vertical timeline showing the negotiation status with discrete visual states. Each node has a one-line label and context. Completed states show a purple checkmark. The current state pulses subtly to signal the process is alive. 'Your Turn' states use a warm coral accent to capture attention. Response time predictions replace the generic 'Pending' state with informative waiting: 'Rita usually responds in 6 hours.'

visual_spec.layout: Vertical timeline with a 2px line connecting circular state nodes (20px). Each node has label text to the right.
visual_spec.border_radius: 12px for container card, 50% for node circles

typography.heading: Inter, 14px (--text-base), 600 weight for state labels
typography.accent: Inter, 14px, 700 weight for 'Your Turn' urgency label

spacing.gap: 28px between timeline nodes, 12px between node circle and label

visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple for completed nodes and acceptance. Border-color for timeline line and future nodes. Coral (#E85D4C) for action-required 'Your Turn' states. Pulsing animation on current state node uses rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.15) glow.

interaction_spec.default_state: Timeline shows all states up to current. Current state node pulses subtly (scale 1.0 to 1.05, 3s infinite). Future states show as empty circles with dashed labels.
interaction_spec.hover: Completed nodes show timestamp tooltip on hover. Counter-offer node shows 'View changes' link on hover.
interaction_spec.click: Counter-offer node click expands inline diff showing changed terms. 'Your Turn' node shows action buttons (Accept / Counter / Decline).
interaction_spec.animation: New states enter with slide-down and fade-in (300ms). Current state pulse uses ease-in-out infinite. State changes cross-fade (500ms).
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, timeline stays left-aligned. Labels stack below nodes for narrow screens. Action buttons become full-width.

copy_spec.micro_copy: States: 'Proposal Sent · Today at 3:42 PM', 'Host Reviewing · Rita usually responds in 6 hours', 'Your Turn · Rita countered with 4 nights/week'. Action: 'Review counter-proposal'

elements.html_css:
Your proposal to Rita
Mon–Fri for 2 months · $85/night · $3,400 total
Proposal Sent
Today at 3:42 PM
Rita Responded
Today at 7:15 PM · Counter-proposal
Changed: 4 nights/week (was 5)
Unchanged: 2 months · $85/night
Your Turn
Review Rita's counter-proposal. She suggested 4 nights/week instead of 5.
Agreement or next steps
elements.test_strategy: A/B test (tests-004): three notification frequency variants (4h/8h/16h, 6h/12h/24h, 12h/24h/48h). Measure proposal abandonment rate and notification dismissal rate. Target: identify variant with lowest abandonment and sub-20% dismissal rate.
elements.coherence_notes: Merges with existing Proposal Progress Pipeline (guest-communicates-005) and Proposal Pipeline as Anxiety-Resolving Status Stream (guest-behaves-004). Adds concrete timing specs and counter-offer diff visualization. The warm coral accent (#E85D4C) for 'Your Turn' states is a new color -- Layer 6 recommended evaluation against existing signal-warn before adoption.

elements.name: Booking Confirmation with Next-Steps Roadmap
elements.problem_it_solves: The Susan call ended with ambiguous next steps and human promises ('I'll keep you updated') -- the acceptance screen must replace verbal promises with a visible, concrete sequence.
elements.description: A booking confirmation screen that produces grounded confidence, not celebration. It restates key terms in plain language, shows the cancellation guarantee as an active safety net, and presents a three-step 'What happens next' roadmap. No confetti, no exclamation marks -- just clear information that makes the unknown feel navigable.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical stack. Confirmation header with check icon, terms summary card, cancellation guarantee callout, three-step next-steps timeline.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) for cards, 1px solid rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.2) for guarantee callout

typography.heading: Inter, 20px, 700 weight, color #1a1a1a for 'Confirmed'
typography.body: DM Sans, 14px, 400 weight, color #374151 for terms details
typography.accent: Inter, 13px, 600 weight, color rgb(109, 49, 194) for guarantee text

visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple for the confirmation check icon and guarantee callout -- trust color in confirmation context. Neutral text colors for terms. No celebratory colors.

interaction_spec.default_state: All sections visible on load. Confirmation appears with a subtle scale (0.98 to 1.0) over 300ms -- weight without drama.
interaction_spec.hover: Steps in the roadmap show subtle highlight on hover.
interaction_spec.click: Guarantee callout click expands to show full cancellation terms. 'View House Manual' link navigates to the pre-arrival guide.
interaction_spec.animation: Next-steps timeline fades in sequentially (200ms stagger per step), creating the feeling of a reliable plan unfolding.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, layout stays single-column. All content visible without horizontal scroll.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Mon-Fri for 8 weeks at Rita's condo. Total: $3,400.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Guarantee: 'Your first night is protected by the cancellation guarantee.' Steps: '1. Check-in details arrive March 2', '2. Open the House Manual on arrival', '3. Complete the verification checklist'. Link: 'View House Manual'

elements.html_css:
Confirmed
Your stay at Rita's condo is booked
Schedule Mon–Fri
Duration 8 weeks (40 nights)
Start date March 3, 2026
Nightly rate $85
Total $3,400
Your first night is protected. Cancel within 24 hours if the space doesn't match the listing.
What happens next
1
Check-in details arrive March 2
We'll send access instructions 24 hours before your first night.
2
Open the House Manual on arrival
Step-by-step guide for accessing the building and verifying the space. Preview House Manual
3
Complete the verification checklist
Confirm the space matches the listing. If it doesn't, the cancellation guarantee is active.
elements.test_strategy: Survey acceptance screen users: 'After seeing this screen, do you know (a) what you committed to, (b) what happens next, and (c) what to do if the space doesn't match?' Target: 90%+ answer all three correctly. Secondary: measure time from acceptance to House Manual preview click.
elements.coherence_notes: Implements feels-004 (grounded confidence, not celebration). Directly addresses the ambiguous handoff at the end of the Susan call (6:50-6:57). The next-steps roadmap replaces Bryant's verbal promise 'I'll keep you updated' with a visible, concrete sequence.

elements.name: Move-In House Manual with Verification Checklist
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan's friend flies from Oregon to a space she has never seen -- the gap between listing signifiers and physical reality is maximum, and the only safety mechanism (cancellation guarantee) was a verbal improvisation.
elements.description: A mobile-first House Manual organized as a chronological action sequence (Access, Verify, Connect, Safety Net, Settle, Explore) with an interactive verification checklist at Step 2 and a persistent cancellation guarantee banner at the bottom. Each step is a card that maps to the guest's physical actions at arrival. The verification checklist presents listing claims as confirmable items -- confirming an item converts anxiety into verified trust, one checkmark at a time.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical scrolling page with numbered step cards. Each card occupies roughly one mobile screen. Persistent bottom banner (fixed position) for cancellation guarantee.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-light) page, var(--bg-white) for active step card, var(--bg-light-gray) for upcoming steps
visual_spec.border_radius: 12px for step cards, 0 for persistent banner

typography.heading: Inter, 18px (--text-lg), 600 weight for step titles
typography.body: DM Sans, 14px, 400 weight, #374151 for step content
typography.accent: Inter, 12px, 600 weight, white on gradient-purple-primary for banner

spacing.gap: 12px between step cards, 10px between checklist items

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple at 0.08 opacity for large background step numerals. Gradient purple for cancellation banner -- the most important safety signal uses the strongest brand treatment. Secondary purple for confirmed checklist icons. Border-color for pending checklist icons.

interaction_spec.default_state: Steps 1-6 visible as a scrollable sequence. Step 1 (Access) expanded with full content. Steps 2-6 show title only, collapsed. Cancellation banner fixed at bottom.
interaction_spec.click: Checklist items have two actions: confirm (check icon, green border) and flag (flag icon, amber). Confirming collapses the item (250ms). Flagging expands a sub-flow with text input and 'Contact Host' button. Banner tap opens cancellation detail sheet.
interaction_spec.animation: Confirmed checklist items collapse with smooth height reduction (250ms). Flagged items expand (300ms). When all items confirmed, a success message fades in. Banner uses slide-up entrance on page load.
interaction_spec.responsive: Designed mobile-first. On desktop, max-width 520px centered. Banner adapts to safe-area-inset-bottom for notch devices.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Step-by-step, one thing at a time.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Step 1: 'Access the building. Code: 4721. 3rd floor, unit 3B.' Step 2: 'Verify the space. Private bathroom? Private room? Wi-Fi works?' Banner: 'Not what you expected? Cancel within 24 hours.' Checklist success: 'Everything matches. Enjoy your stay.'

elements.html_css:
Your Move-In Guide
Rita's Condo · North Bergen, NJ
1
1
Access the building
Address: 742 Palisade Ave, 3rd Floor, Unit 3B
Entry code: 4721
Key: Lockbox to the left of the door
Floor: 3rd floor walk-up, no elevator
Need help? Contact Rita
2
2
Verify the space
Tap to confirm each item matches the listing.
Private room as shown in photos
Private bathroom
Wi-Fi works
Co-occupancy as described
3
Connect to Wi-Fi
4
House rules & quiet hours
5
Neighborhood basics
Not what you expected? Cancel within 24 hours.
elements.test_strategy: Contextual inquiry (tests-006): observe 8 real guests during their first-night move-in. Target: 75%+ access the House Manual within 10 minutes of arrival, 60%+ complete the verification checklist, zero guests encounter a critical access issue not covered by the manual.
elements.coherence_notes: Previously the weakest phase in the library. This is the Norman lens's most distinctive contribution. The chronological organization (Access, Verify, Connect, Safety Net, Settle, Explore) replaces topic-based manuals. The interactive verification checklist is the digital enactment of Susan's three-time demand to 'see the space and make sure everything is legit.'
